reading_mnemonic: The word for sack (ふくろ) is rendaku'd, so be careful of that.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened いち.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened 一 and the rendaku in this one.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 万 and 人 both have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:

<vocabulary>All people</vocabulary> have been <reading>ban</reading>ned from <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (ばんにん). Apparently they're working on something super secret, so now <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary> is banned. What could it be?!
不孝 is a reading you should know already. Add the もの reading for 者 and you have yourself a reading. Now go be obedient to your parents and keep studying your kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The readings are both kun'yomi readings, combined. For 人 you'll just have to remember this. With 柄 that's the reading you learned anyways, so that makes things easier. Just keep it consistent!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one used here. They're a <vocabulary>pair</vocabulary>, you know?
The reading is like 二人, (the ふた part) plus 子, combined together. A little weird, but makes sense. Watch out for the rendaku.

The 鏡 part uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. To remember this, just think about how when you look down binoculars, you see something strange (like a strange reading for 鏡). That strange thing you see through these fantastic binoculars is... tomorrow. Your binoculars are so strong that you can already see tomorrow, <reading>today</reading> (きょう)!
The readings are of 口笛 and the reading you learned from 吹.
The readings come from 吹く and 出す.
The reading comes from the word 吹く and the kanji 込む.
The reading comes from 吹く and 飛ばす, put together.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What's the first two letters of the word <vocabulary>mourning</vocabulary>? It's <reading>mo</reading> (も). You can use that to remember.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The readings are the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. 国 is くに and 柄 is the reading you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
The reading for 干 is an exceptional one. Just think to why the lagoon is dry. It's because of the <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) of the sun. Watch out for the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 投 when you learned 投資 a long time ago.

Both of these kanji take the on'yomi, but the first one has a slightly irregular reading, because it's based on the modern Chinese reading. To remember that it's a long らー, just think how excited you are about these ramen! <reading>Raaaaaa</reading>! Raaaamen! So exciting!
You are fastening up the <reading>coocoo</reading> (くく) clock, so the coocoo bird doesn't come out anymore. That annoying coocoo bird.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, watch out from the shortening.
<reading>I do</reading>n't (いど) just challenge anyone, but when I challenge someone, it's for real. My challenging reflexes come from my <reading>Id</reading> (いど), after all.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
If you are going <vocabulary>to dig</vocabulary> you are going to end up making a <reading>ho</reading>le (ほ).

For 掛 you'll want to think back to the word 掛ける, then shorten it and shove it into the kanji half way (the かけ part at least). For 軸 that's the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that to work off of.
Remember the other "to raise" vocabs? They are all あげる as well. For example, 上げる is あげる and 挙げる is あげる as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go <vocabulary>to grasp</vocabulary> someone. You really need them. You are soooo <reading>needy</reading> (にぎ). Except, you can't really pronounce "d" sounds very well, so you say にぎ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. With 手 just think back to other vocab words that use the on'yomi reading.
If everything starts <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary> what else will shake along with it? <reading>You</reading> (ゆ), of course.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the readings of 携帯 and 電話 for this one.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 場 when you learned 入場 ages ago.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>For a little while</vocabulary>, we're going to listen to <reading>shiba rock</reading> (しばらく). This is a form of rock and roll performed by shiba dogs. You should look up shiba inu puppy pictures if you haven't ever heard of shiba inus.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The readings come from the readings you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck. Follow that reading pattern to here, and you should be okay.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
We are just going to stay <reading>to</reading>night (と) and maybe <reading>to</reading>morrow (と) night.

You're about <vocabulary>to slip</vocabulary>, and notice the floor is covered entirely in <reading>souve</reading>nirs (すべ)! Souvenirs of all shapes and sizes are scattered all over the floor, making it extremely easy to slide and slip.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 漬ける, so you should be able to read this one too.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

You know the reading for 飯, but 炒 uses an exceptional reading that you didn't learn. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

Do you know what would bring your <vocabulary>fried rice</vocabulary> to the next level? Some <reading>char</reading>coal (ちゃー)! Next time, just add a little charcoal to your fried rice, and it'll taste so much better. Trust me on this one.
The times where you were burned were mostly when you were a <reading>子</reading> (こ). That's because kids aren't good at working with hot things.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 飛 just think about how <reading>he</reading> (ひ) hit a sacrifice fly, and he hit it so hard the ball <reading>he</reading>ated up.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the 発 getting shortened.
The reading is 福 and 袋, put together. Also, watch out for the rendaku.
The reading is the same as the one you learned as well!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need <vocabulary>to divert</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to distract</vocabulary> <reading>Maggie</reading> (まぎ).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The first kanji has a slightly irregular reading because it's prolonged. That's because <vocabulary>somen</vocabulary> are your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) food.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading used here is the reading you learned with the kanji.
The readings are from 綱 and 引く.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When it comes to <vocabulary>net</vocabulary>s, you gotta go talk to <reading>Amy</reading> (あみ) if you want a good one. Only Amy makes good nets.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Your <vocabulary>liver</vocabulary> isn't doing great. You have cancer in your liver, so now they're giving you <reading>chemo</reading> (きも) to help get rid of that cancer.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

The reading for 芝 is the one you learned with the kanji. The reading for 生 is one you haven't seen before (exception). It's ふ, and you can remember it by thinking how you were such a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) for putting all that poison on it. Now it's dying, and now it's becoming less of a lawn.
This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you learned already!
The reading is one of the readings you've learned from the kanji. The あら one.
The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. While you've learned these for both of the kanji, 装 actually uses one you haven't learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You know whose wardrobe was definitely full of special <vocabulary>clothing</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>costume</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>outfit</vocabulary>s? The <reading>sho</reading>gun's (しょう)! Know all those old-timey looking paintings of shoguns in their regal attire? Just think of that when you have to remember this reading for 装!
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. So, put that knowledge in a <vocabulary>sack</vocabulary> and move on to the next item.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading for 不孝 is the one you learned. Then, add 親's reading (vocab) to it.
The reading is 孝行 plus the kun'yomi of 親. Put them together and you'll become a good filial child.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

You learned the に reading for this kanji when you learned 逃げる.

If you have trouble telling the two words apart, remember that if you're going <vocabulary>to let go</vocabulary> of someone, make sure they have their <reading>knee gua</reading>rds (にが). It's a dangerous world, you can't have them running free without some extra protection, you know.
This is the same reading you learned for 逃す, so you should be able to read this word as well.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
If you know the meaning, you should be able to read this too. After all, <vocabulary>mochi</vocabulary> is <reading>mochi</reading> (もち)!
The readings come from 駆ける and 出す.
The readings come from 駆ける and 回る.
The readings come from 駆ける and 込む.
